an5.109:4.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities has all four directions covered.
an5.109:4.3: It’s when mendicant is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, and accomplished in appropriate behavior and means of collecting alms. Seeing danger in the slightest flaw, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5.109:4.4: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and understanding them with right view.
an5.109:4.5: They’re content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
an5.109:4.6: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5.109:4.7: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
an5.109:4.8: A mendicant with these five qualities has all four directions covered.”
